sentence: Markets sold off following the released Fed minutes from last month which came out yesterday afternoon.
Concerns about the well-being of markets around the world and continued lower oil prices informed the members' viewpoints.
Global markets followed the U.S. markets downward overnight Thursday, with China remaining soft and Germany experiencing an economic low ebb that is its worst in 3 years.
Oil prices are also dipping toward $40 per barrel, which hasn't been seen since the peak of the Great Recession.
Crude is, in fact, down more than 3.5x its multi-year peak of around $147 per barrel, if anyone dares looking back as far as July 2008.
Q2 earnings season - no one's ideas of a raging success - were negatively affected to a huge extent by weakness in the Energy sector, which remains tethered to oil and gas prices.

Although the Fed also noted an improving job market - the biggest component currently toward the Reserve's leaning toward raising interest rates next month - analysts now see a diminished possibility of a rate hike in the next couple weeks.
This would kick the can toward the Fed's December meeting, and depending on the data might push the initial hike into early 2016.
Speaking of the U.S. job market, Jobless Claims pushed upward for the week to 277K, up 4K from last week's 273K, which was revised down a thousand jobs since last month's initial reading.
Continuing claims are down somewhat to 2.25 million from 2.28 million last month.
Reporting earnings today are still a few big names: Hewlett-Packard ( HPQ ), Salesforce.com ( CRM ) and Gap ( GPS ).
While H-P is currently a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell), the company has narrowly beat earnings expectations over the past 3 quarters.
Salesforce is a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold), but Gap has struggled meetings earnings and is also a Zacks Rank #4.
